guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Breadboard Jumper Wires
  • ATmega 328P microcontroller, with Optiboot
  • 16MHz crystal
  • 10uF capacitors
  • 0.1uF capacitor
  • 22pF capacitors
  • 220 ohm resistor
  • 10K ohm Resistors
  • LED
  • 5V voltage regulator
  • FTDI Basic Breakout board
  • 6-9V power supply and connector

lines.text: Connect your power supply connector to the board.
lines.text_raw: Connect your power supply connector to the board.

lines.text: add a 10uF decoupling capacitor across the supply pins. Note that these capacitors are polarised, so you’ll need to connect the side with the negative indicator (look for a stripe or -ve sign – or check your datasheet) to GND, and the other to +ve.
lines.text_raw: add a 10uF decoupling capacitor across the supply pins. Note that these capacitors are polarised, so you’ll need to connect the side with the negative indicator (look for a stripe or -ve sign – or check your datasheet) to GND, and the other to +ve.

lines.text: add the regulator, ensuring that the external supply positive lead connects to the input , and the negative to the GND.  Check your datasheet carefully.
lines.text_raw: add the regulator, ensuring that the external supply positive lead connects to the input , and the negative to the GND.  Check your datasheet carefully.

lines.text: Connect the other 10uF capacitor to the GND and output from the regulator, and then take leads from the GND and output to the power rails of your breadboard.  This power is "clean" and will be at 5V.
lines.text_raw: Connect the other 10uF capacitor to the GND and output from the regulator, and then take leads from the GND and output to the power rails of your breadboard.  This power is "clean" and will be at 5V.

lines.text: add leads to connect the 2 power rails from your board so that they are both powered.
lines.text_raw: add leads to connect the 2 power rails from your board so that they are both powered.

lines.text: Finally, let’s add a LED to show when the board is powered.  Connect a 10k resistor from the GND rail to the cathode of the LED (the shorter leg), and run a wire to connect the anode to the positive rail.  I’ve used a blue 3mm LED, and the 10k resistor so that it doesn’t burn too brightly.
